Soviet offensive phase in 1944 

Air raids and political development

Finland began to actively seek a way out of the war after the disastrous German defeat at the Battle of Stalingrad in February 1943. Prime Minister Edwin Linkomies formed a new cabinet in March 1943 with peace as the top priority. Negotiations were conducted intermittently during 1943–1944 between Finland, the Western Allies and the USSR, but no agreement was reached. Stalin decided to force Finland to surrender with a bombing campaign on Helsinki starting in February 1944. It included three major air attacks with a total of over 6,000 sorties. Finnish anti-aircraft defence managed to repel the raids as only five per cent of the dropped bombs hit their planned targets. For example in Helsinki, searchlights and fires were placed as decoys outside the city to lure Soviet bombers to drop their payloads in what were actually unpopulated areas. Major air attacks also hit Oulu and Kotka, but pre-emptive radio intelligence and effective defence kept the number of casualties small. Meanwhile, the persistent German and Estonian defence in Narva from February to August eliminated Soviet-occupied Estonia as a favourable base for amphibious invasions and air attacks against Helsinki and other Finnish coastal cities tu support a land offensive. Field Marshal Mannerheim had repeatedly reminded the German command that in case their troops in Estonia retreated, Finland would be forced to make peace even on extremely unfavourable terms.Howard D. Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive 

On 9 June 1944, the Soviet Leningrad Front launched a strategic offensive against Finnish positions on the Karelian Isthmus and in the area of Lake Ladoga, timed to accompany the Allied Operation Overlord in Normandy, France.Declaration of the Three Powers, December 1, 1943, Tehran Conference On the -wide breakthrough segment, the Red Army concentrated 3,000 guns and mortars. In some places, the concentration of artillery pieces exceeded 200 guns for every kilometre of the front or one for every 5 m. Soviet artillery fired over 80,000 rounds along the front on the Karelian Isthmus. On the second day of the offensive, the artillery barrages and superior number of Soviet forces crushed the main Finnish defence line. The Red Army penetrated the second line of defence, Vammelsuu–Taipale line (VT line), by the sixth day and recaptured Vyborg almost without a fight by 20 June. The Soviet breakthrough on the Karelian Isthmus forced the Finns to reinforce the area. This allowed the parallel Soviet offensive in East Karelia by the Karelian Front to meet less resistance and to recapture Petrozavodsk by 28 June 1944. The main objective of the Soviet strategic offensive was to force Finland out from the war.Erickson 1993, p. 197Gebhardt 1989, p. 2Glantz 1998, p. 202

On 25 June, the Red Army reached the third line of defence, the Viipuri–Kuparsaari–Taipale line (VKT line), and the decisive Battle of Tali-Ihantala began, described as the largest battle in Nordic military history. At this point, the Finnish Army had retreated around  to approximately the same line of defence they had held at the end of the Winter War. Finland especially lacked modern anti-tank weaponry that could stop Soviet heavy armour, such as the KV-1 or IS-2. Peace 

Several Western historians state that Soviet designs for Finland were no different from their designs for the Baltic countries. American political scientist Dan Reiter asserts that for Moscow the control of Finland was necessary. Reiter and British historian Victor Rothwell both quote Molotov telling his Lithuanian counterpart, at the time when Lithuania was effectively absorbed into the USSR, that minor countries, such as Finland, "will be included within the honourable family of Soviet peoples."Dan Reiter, How Wars End, Princeton University Press, Princeton, New Jersey USA (2009), p. 131. Russian historian Nikolai Baryshnikov disputes the view that the Soviet Union wanted to deprive Finland of its independence. He argues that there is no documentary evidence for such claims and that the Soviet government was always open for negotiations. Baryshnikov cites, for example, the former public information chief of Finnish Headquarters, Major Kalle Lehmus, to show that Finland's leadership learned of the limited Soviet plans for Finland at least by July 1944 after intelligence indicated that some Soviet divisions were to be transferred to reserve in Leningrad.Baryshnikov (2002), pp. 222–23 (Section heading "Стремительный прорыв," paragraph #48 et seq., after cit. 409)Baryshnikov (2006) Reiter states that the fear of severe losses pushed Stalin to accept a limited outcome in the war rather than pursue annexation although some Soviet documentation called for military occupation of Finland.Dan Reiter, How Wars End, Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ (2009), pp. 138, 135. He argues that the Finnish victory at the Battle of Ilomantsi persuaded the USSR to give up their plan for an unconditional surrender of the Finns.Dan Reiter, How Wars End, Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ (2009), p. 136.
